availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: James Thomas Goalder (Green County, Kentucky, attorney.)

body.p: Green County, Kentucky, attorney. Green County, Kentucky, native. Son of Christopher Goalder and Henrietta Sandridge Goalder. Married to Sarah Wilson Goalder. Father of Theodore Goalder, Henrietta Goalder, Florence Goalder, Wilson W. Goalder, Edwin R. Goalder, and Elwood C. Goalder. Resident of Green County, Kentucky, in 1840. Owned nine enslaved persons in Green County in 1840. Attorney in Green County in 1850. Owned three enslaved persons in Green County in 1850. Attorney in Green County in 1860.

ab.bibl:
Sixth Manuscript Census of the United States (1840), Kentucky, Green County, p, 182.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Green County, District 2, p. 154B.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Green County, District 2.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Green County, District 2, p. 542.
William B. Allen, A History of Kentucky: Embracing Gleanings, Reminiscences, Antiquities, Natural Curiosities, Statistics, and Biographical Sketches of Pioneers, Soldiers, Jurists, Lawyers, Statesmen, Divines, Mechanics, Farmers, Merchants, and Other Leading Men, of All Occupations and Pursuits (Louisville, KY: Bradley & Gilbert, 1872), 369-70.
Charles Kerr, William Elsey Connelley, and E.M. Coulter, History of Kentucky, vol. IV (Chicago: The American Historical Society, 1922), 398.
Lineage Book: National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, vol. LVIII (Washington, D.C.: Judd & Detweiler, Inc., 1921), 26.
